stem: A 62-year-old client presents with crushing substernal chest pain and shortness of breath. Based on the documentation in the Critical Cardiopulmonary & Strain Marker Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Rule out acute coronary syndrome vs. pulmonary obstruction.
Background: History of smoking and recent long-haul flight (14 hours).
Assessment: BP is dropping. Client is pale and diaphoretic. Chest pain is sharp and worse with deep breaths (Pleuritic).
Recommendation: Troponin and CT scan.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 92/58, HR 128, RR 32, T 99.2Â°F. SpO2 84% on RA.

conditionOptions.text: Massive Pulmonary Embolism (PE) with Right Heart Strain

actionOptions.text: Elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees and provide high-flow oxygen
Initiate IV Heparin and prepare for pulmonary angiography (CT-PE)
Encourage the client to cough and deep breathe vigorously
Place the client in a left-lateral Trendelenburg position (Durant's)

parameterOptions.text: Presence of right ventricular strain on EKG (S1Q3T3 pattern)
SpO2 levels and respiratory effort (Dyspnea assessment)
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is a Massive Pulmonary Embolism (c2). While the chest pain and elevated Troponin suggest an MI, the S1Q3T3 pattern (Specific for PE) on the EKG and the massive D-Dimer (4200) point to the lungs. The Right Heart is straining against the clot (Elevated BNP/Troponin). Priority actions are oxygenation optimization (a1) and immediate anticoagulation (a2). Key parameters include tracking the strain patterns (p1) and pulmonary stability (p2).
clinicalPearls: The S1Q3T3 pattern (Prominent S in lead I, Q and inverted T in lead III) is the classic but rare EKG sign for massive PE.
Troponin rises in PE because the RIGHT ventricle is undergoing muscle damage from the pressure, not because of a heart attack in the coronary arteries.
A BP of 92/58 makes this a 'Massive' PE (Submassive has normal BP).

questionTrap.trap: Thinking an elevated Troponin *always* means a heart attack (MI).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Troponin is a marker of heart muscle *stress*. If the patient has 82% SpO2 and a massive D-Dimer, the heart is stressed because the lungs are blocked (PE), not because of a clogged artery.

mnemonic.title: PE-Strain
mnemonic.expansion: S-S1Q3T3. T-Troponin Up. R-Right Heart Failure. A-Angiogram (CT). I-Infarction mimic. N-NRB Mask (High O2).
